doc.title: AEJ Week Ahead: August PMIs and CPIs Korea Exports, BNM meeting
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/GS/AEJ Week Ahead August PMIs and CPIs Korea Exports BNM meetingAEJ Week Ahead August PMIs and CPIs Korea Exports BNM meeti_2025-08-29

passages.text: Scheduled key data releases for the conference week in Asia ex- Japan include August PMIs and CPIs across the region, trade data in Korea, and a central bank meeting in Malaysia. Below we summarize our forecasts and expectations for these releases and events.

- August PMIs (August 31 and September 1): We expect the NBS manufacturing PMI to stay flat at 49.3 in August. The emerging Industries PMI stayed roughly unchanged in August after seasonal adjustment. However, high-frequency indicators such as steel production ticked up marginally in August. We expect the RatingDog manufacturing PMI (formerly the Caixin manufacturing PMI) to increase to 50.0 in August from 49.5 in July on a slight increase in export growth momentum as suggested by high-frequency shipping data. We expect the NBS nonmanufacturing PMI to rise to 50.3 in August from 50.1 in July. Services PMI should increase on improvement in the financial services sector. Adverse weather conditions likely continued to disrupt construction activity in August.

- Korea August trade (September 1): We expect Korea's exports to rise 1.0% mom sa in August, with the momentum gaining slightly from 0.7% the previous month. Implied year-on-year growth would be 4.0% (vs. Bloomberg consensus: 1.5% at the time of writing), moderating slightly from 5.8% the previous month. Exports data for early August suggest that gains were led by semiconductors and autos. We expect imports growth to fall 2.5% yoy (vs. Bloomberg consensus: -2.9% yoy), and the trade surplus to widen to US\(7.5bn from US\)6.6bn the prior month.

- Korea August CPI (September 2): We expect Korea's headline CPI inflation to fall to 1.7% yoy in August (vs. Bloomberg consensus: 1.9% at the time of writing) from 2.1% the previous month. We expect the sequential momentum to fall to 2.0% mom sa, driven primarily by a one-off 50% discount in mobile phone charges by a major telco operator during the month. We expect the negative impact could be partially offset by higher prices of fresh produce and non-oil products. Core CPI will likely drop more given the higher weight of mobile phone charges.

TaiwanAugust CPI (September 5): We expect Taiwan's headline CPI inflation to edge up to \(1.7\%\) yoy in August from \(1.5\%\) yoy in July (vs. Bloomberg consensus: \(1.6\%\) yoy at the time of writing) in part due to the supply impact of seasonal typhoons. Sequentially, we expect a slight acceleration in headline CPI momentum to \(0.4\%\) mom sa from \(0.3\%\) the prior month. High- frequency data suggests sharper gains in fresh food prices to drive the headline momentum, with resumed declines in prices of fuel products partially offsetting the gains.

Indonesia August CPI (September 1): We expect headline CPI inflation to increase to \(2.6\%\) yoy in August (Bloomberg consensus: \(2.5\%\) yoy) from \(2.4\%\) yoy in July. On a sequential, seasonally adjusted basis, we expect headline CPI to rise \(0.4\%\) mom s.a. in August (vs. \(0.3\%\) mom s.a. in July) on the reversal of the travel discounts announced by the government in June and higher rice and red onion prices.

Bank Negara Malaysia meeting (September 4): We expect the Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM) to keep its overnight policy rate (OPR) on hold at \(2.75\%\) at its meeting next week, in line with Bloomberg consensus at the time of writing. Since the "pre- emptive" cut at the previous meeting, headline and core inflation remained subdued, while high- frequency activity data generally improved. Industrial production gained \(2.8\%\) mom sa in June ahead of a sharp \(14.6\%\) rebound in July exports driven by stronger demand from EM Asia. Manufacturing PMI also improved in July. Labor markets remained strong with the unemployment rate at decade- low levels and the participation rate at historically high levels. Overall, we expect the BNM to keep the policy rate at \(2.75\%\) for the remainder of this year, with risk skewed to another cut should the economy slow meaningfully.

Thailand September CPI (September 4): We expect headline CPI deflation to further deepen to \(- 0.8\%\) yoy in August (Bloomberg consensus: \(- 0.8\%\) yoy) from \(- 0.7\%\) yoy in July. On a sequential, seasonally adjusted basis, we expect headline CPI to fall \(0.1\%\) in August (vs. \(- 0.2\%\) mom s.a. in July) mainly due to lower pork and vegetable prices.

Philippines August CPI (September 5): We expect headline CPI inflation to increase to \(1.5\%\) yoy in August (Bloomberg consensus: \(1.1\%\) yoy) from \(0.9\%\) yoy in July. On a sequential, seasonally adjusted basis, we expect headline CPI to rise \(0.6\%\) mom s.a. in August (vs. \(0.1\%\) mom s.a. in July) mainly due to higher vegetable and fish prices and electricity tariffs.

Key data/events to watch outside the region include: : PMIs, durable goods orders, nonfarm payrolls, and unemployment rate from the US; Eurozone's flash CPI inflation, unemployment rate, and retail sales; Japan's household real consumption as well as Australia's PMIs and trade data

The Bank of Korea's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) kept its policy rate unchanged at \(2.5\%\) , in line with expectations. One MPC member cast a dissenting vote cast in a cut to \(2.25\%\) , for the first time since April. MPC forward guidance also turned more dovish, with 5 out of 6 members (up from 4 in the previous meeting) open to a further cut in the next three months. The BOK revised up its 2025 growth and headline CPI inflation forecast by 0.1pp each to \(0.9\%\) and \(2.0\%\) respectively. We continue to expect one more 25bp cut in October to \(2.25\%\) . Our baseline projection for the terminal rate remains at \(2.25\%\) , with the balance of risk tilted slightly to \(2.0\%\) .

Korea's headline IP rose \(0.3\%\) mom sa in July, extending gains after increasing \(1.7\%\) the prior month. The outcome was broadly in line with Bloomberg consensus. Manufacturing gains were led by electronic parts and machinery. Consumption indicators improved, with retail sales recording the strongest momentum since February 2023, while investment indicators were mixed. Overall output gained \(0.3\%\) .

Taiwan's industrial production (IP) fell \(1.4\%\) mom sa in July, down after a \(4.2\%\) contraction the prior month. The outcome was slightly above Bloomberg consensus. The weakness was most pronounced in computers, electronic and optical products, for which production dropped \(17.6\%\) after sharp gains in earlier months. Consumption indicators generally weakened.

Singapore's headline CPI inflation slowed to \(0.6\%\) yoy in July (vs. \(0.8\%\) yoy in June) mainly driven by slower accommodation inflation. Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) core CPI inflation, which excludes private transportation and accommodation, also edged down to \(0.5\%\) yoy in July from \(0.6\%\) yoy in June as lower electricity tariffs and clothes prices were partially offset by higher holiday expenses.

The Monetary Board (MB) of Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) cut the policy rate by 25bp, reducing the overnight lending rate, overnight RRP rate and overnight deposit rate to \(5.50\%\) \(5.00\%\) and \(4.50\%\) , respectively. Ahead of the meeting, all panelists in the Bloomberg survey (including us) had expected a 25bp rate cut. Going forward, given our expectations of slower global growth in 2H 2025 and our more dovish Fed outlook (vs. the market pricing), we continue to expect BSP to cut policy rates by another 50bp in the cycle - 25bp each in Q4 and Q1 2026 - to \(4.50\%\) . The next BSP meeting is scheduled on October 9.

The Constitutional Court has dismissed Thai Prime Minister, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, for "ethics violation" involving the leaked audio recording of her conversation on June 15 with Hun Sen, the former President of Cambodia. The next steps would be

for the Lower House to elect a new Prime Minister. We note that last year, when the Constitutional Court dismissed the then Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin on 14th August, the parliament vote took place 2 days later on 16th August. We would therefore expect that a Lower House vote is likely to take place within the coming week. Meanwhile, Phumtham Vechayachai of the Pheu Thai Party has been serving as acting Prime Minister since Paetongtarn was suspended in July 2025.

Please see Asia Economics Analyst 15/17: "The sensitivity of Asian financial markets to economic data" and Asia Economics Analyst: "How global macro data affect AEJ financial markets" for an analysis of the market impact of regional economic data using high- frequency (intraday) data across ten emerging Asia economies. We find markets have consistent short- term reactions to some of the highest- profile economic indicators, particularly industrial production, GDP, trade data, and inflation.

This research is focused on investment themes across markets, industries and sectors. It does not attempt to distinguish between the prospects or performance of, or provide analysis of, individual companies within any industry or sector we describe.

Any trading recommendation in this research relating to an equity or credit security or securities within an industry or sector is reflective of the investment theme being discussed and is not a recommendation of any such security in isolation.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators.
